abstract.title: EPUB3 Overview
abstract.para: EPUB3 is the third major revision of an interchange and delivery format for digital publications based on XML and Web Standards. EPUB3 is defined by a set of specification documents, including this document. This document serves as the overall introduction to EPUB3, describing the other EPUB3 documents and reviewing cross-cutting concerns including accessibility, metadata, and global language support.

section.title: Purpose and Scope
section.para: This document, the EPUB3 Overview, describes the third major revision of EPUB, a digital publication interchange and delivery format based on XML and Web Standards.

This document is intended to provide a starting point for content authors and software developers wishing to understand EPUB3. It consists of non-normative overview material, including a roadmap for the four building-block specification documents that compose EPUB3:

This document also provides non-normative information about cross-cutting concerns applicable to EPUB usage, including sections on accessibility, scripting, metadata, fonts, text-to-speech features, and global language support.

Another non-normative document, EPUB3 Changes from EPUB 2.0.1 , describes changes in EPUB3 from the previous version. This document is intended primarily for s and vendors migrating from EPUB 2.0.1 to EPUB3, or those who anticipate supporting both versions.

chapter.title: Introduction
chapter.para: The EPUB specification is a distribution and interchange format standard for digital publications and documents. EPUB defines a means of representing, packaging and encoding structured and semantically enhanced Web content — including HTML5, CSS, SVG, images, and other resources — for distribution in a single-file format.

The EPUB specification has been widely adopted as the format for digital books (eBooks), and EPUB3 significantly increases the format's capabilities in order to better support a wider range of publication requirements, including complex layouts, rich media and interactivity, and global typography features. The expectation is that EPUB3 will be utilized for a broad range of content, including books, magazines and educational, professional and scientific publications.

chapter.title: EPUB3 Publications
chapter.para: Each has a well-defined reading order and includes a declarative means of navigating its content. In addition to including semantically rich metadata, the content also meets reliability constraints — including the use of XML serialization and separation of scripting from other content — intended to enable dynamic rendering, such as paginated formatting and text-to-speech, based on device characteristics and User preferences.

An EPUB Publication is typically bundled as a ZIP-based archive with the file extension .epub for distribution. As conformant ZIP archives, Publications can be unzipped by many software programs, simplifying both their production and consumption. A minimal "Hello World" EPUB file that has been unzipped into a directory may comprise three files, and might look like the following example:

While conceptually simple, an EPUB file is more than just a collection of HTML pages and dependent assets in a ZIP package. A key concept of EPUB is that a Publication consists of multiple resources that may be completely navigated and consumed by a person or program in some specific order. This order can be reliably determined, which is typically not true of a collection of HTML pages.

Many publications have an obvious reading order, or logical progression through their content. A novel is an example of a highly sequential document, as it typically has a beginning, middle and end, but not all publications are so ordered: a cookbook or collection of photographic images might be considered to be more like a database. All documents do, however, have at least one logical ordering of all their top-level content items, whether by date, topic, location or some other criteria (e.g., a cookbook is typically ordered by recipe types).

Every EPUB Publication defines at least one such logical ordering of all its top-level content, as well as a declarative table of contents. Publications make these data structures available in a machine-readable way external to the content items themselves, simplifying their discovery and use.

EPUB Publications are not limited to the linear ordering of their contents, nor do they preclude linking in arbitrary ways — the Web is built on hypertext — but the basic consumption and navigation can be reliably accomplished in a way that is not true for a set of HTML pages.

Another key concept in EPUB is that content presentation should adapt to the , rather than the User having to adapt to a particular presentation of content. HTML was originally designed to support dynamic rendering of structured content, but over time HTML as supported in Web browsers has become focused on the needs of Web applications, and most popular Web sites now have fixed-format layouts. EPUB Publications are designed to maximize accessibility to the visually impaired, and s typically perform text line layout and pagination on the fly, adapting to the size of the display area, the User's preferred font size, and other environmental factors. This behavior is not guaranteed in EPUB — images, vector graphics, video, and other content can be included, and such content may not be reflowable, and some Reading Systems may not do pagination on the fly, or at all — but supporting dynamic adaptive layout and accessibility has been a primary design consideration throughout the evolution of the EPUB standard.

One corollary to this concept is that EPUB strives to treat content declaratively — as data that can be manipulated, not programs that must be executed. So, for example, use of JavaScript scripting in EPUB content documents is disabled by default Garth: is this really true? What about a "script" element found in a content document that isn't correctly declared as containing spine-level scripting? In 2.0.1 this was a "should not execute" the contained script., must be explicitly requested as part of specifying a content document within a larger publication, and may not be supported by all Reading Systems.

The following sections introduce the four major components of EPUB Publications (package file, content documents, media overlays, and container), which correspond to the four building-block specifications that collectively define the EPUB3 format.

section.title: Package Document
section.para: Every EPUB Publication includes a single , an XML document that specifies all its constituent content documents and their required resources, defines a reading order for linear consumption, and associates publication-level metadata and navigation information.

A typical Web site, on the other hand, embeds references to its resources within its content, which, while a simple and flexible means of identifying them, makes it difficult to enumerate all the resources required by a given Web page. As well, there is no standard way for a Web site to define that a sequence of pages make up a larger publication (i.e., there is no external declarative means to explicitly specify navigation through a collection of HTML documents). Likewise, there is no standard way to represent metadata applicable globally to such a collection.
An EPUB Publication's Package Document addresses all of these issues, and declaratively defines the root of the publication. The Package file and other publication-level constructs are specified in .

section.title: Content Documents
section.para: Every EPUB Publication contains one or more , as defined in . These are XHTML or SVG documents that describe the readable content of a Publication and reference associated media resources (e.g., images, audio and video clips).

s are defined by a profile of HTML5 that requires the use of XML serialization in order to ensure that content can be reliably manipulated and rendered. This profile also adds two additional EPUB-specific language constructs: the attribute for element-level metadata and the epub:trigger element for declaratively associating controls with multimedia elements. These additions do not affect the ability of an HTML5 User Agent to render EPUB XHTML Content Documents, but Publications may not render identically in all User Agents (notably, Web browsers typically provide an infinitely scrolling while EPUB Reading Systems typically paginate content).

EPUB Content Documents can optionally reference s to define the desired rendering properties. EPUB3 defines a profile of CSS based on CSS 2.1 for this purpose, together with capabilities defined by various CSS3 Modules as well as several additional properties specific to EPUB. The CSS3 properties that have been selected were done so based on their current level of support by Web browsers, but some properties may not affect rendering by Reading Systems and User Agents (support for the EPUB-defined properties may be similarly inefectual).
Every EPUB3 Publication also contains a special XHTML Content Document called the , which uses the HTML5 nav element to define human- and machine-readable navigation information, as defined in .

The Navigation Document supersedes and obsoletes the NCX document , and the inclusion of NCX documents is only recommended for forward compatiblity in older Reading Systems. The Navigation Document, while maintaining the baseline accessibility and navigation support and features of the NCX, introduces new functionality and rendering features to ehance navigation for all Users. Prime among these are better support for internationalization — as an XHTML5 document itself, the Navigation Document natively supports Ruby — and support for embedded grammars — MathML and SVG can be included within navigation links. As XHTML documents, Navigation Documents also provide a flexible means of tailoring the navigation display using CSS while not impacting access to information for accessible Reading Systems.

section.title: Media Overlays
section.para: An EPUB Publication may optionally contain one or more s, which provide a means to associate pre-recorded audio with textual/visual content to facilitate synchronized playback. Media Overlay Documents are specified via a subset of SMIL, as defined in .

section.title: Container
section.para: An EPUB Publication is transported and interchanged as a single file (a "portable document") that contains the Package Document, all Content Documents, and all other required resources for processing the Publication. The single-file container format for EPUB is based on the widely adopted ZIP format. An XML manifest that specifies the location in the ZIP archive of the package file must be found at a well-defined location within the archive.

This approach provides a clear contract between any creator of an EPUB publication and any system which consumes such publications, as well as a reliable representation that is independent of network transport or file system specifics.
An EPUB publication's representation as a container file is specified in .

chapter.title: EPUB3 Authoring Guidelines
chapter.para: This section covers a number of important topics that span the EPUB3 specifications and apply to the process of authoring s as a whole. As EPUB3 is a new version of the EPUB specification and builds on a number of relatively new Web Standards like HTML5, best practices are still emerging, and the guidelines described here should not be considered an exhaustive or definitive enumeration. s are strongly encouraged to read these guidelines, regardless, and to stay abreast of best practices as they evolve.

section.title: Metadata
section.para: This section reviews the metadata facilities present in EPUB3 from a holistic perspective, and discusses recommended best practices.

section.title: Make Identifiers Unique
section.para: As noted in , a Package Document's Author is responsible for including a primary identifier that is unique to one and only one particular EPUB Publication. This requirement can be challenging, particularly given that the definition of a particular EPUB Publication is inherently fuzzy.

There is no simple solution to the uniqueness problem, however, except to ensure that identifiers are created in a non-trivial fashion. Although EPUB3 does not attempt to formally specify how identifiers should be constructed, some recommendations are to not rely on simple integer values or timestamps alone as the means of identifying Publications. Identifiers that combine spatial, temporal and random character data are significantly less likely to occur in duplicate than those that rely on common data types.

section.title: Persist Identifiers
section.para: Not every release of an EPUB Publication warrants the issuing of a new unique identifier, nor is it typically desirable (especially in the case of minor formatting and errata fixes). A Publication's unique identifier represents the primary means of referencing and linking to the Publication, and also assists in distribution channels to identify that the Publication does not represent a new instance. Changing this identifier should consequently only be undertaken when the Publication must be identified and handled as a new instance.

Persisting the identifier, however, causes the secondary problem of needing to reliably distinguish one version of the same Publication from another. EPUB3 adds the for exactly this purpose. The Package Identifier is created by combining the unique identifier with the last modification date of the Publication to create a new identifier that can be used to sequentially order different releases of the same Publication. Authors are consequently encouraged to use this method of identification to release updates than the practice of creating a new unique identifier each time.

section.title: Global Language Support
section.para: This section reviews the global language facilities present in EPUB3 that support Asian and other non-Roman content. It discusses recommended best practices for ensuring that content is suitable for global distribution.

section.title: Embed Fonts
section.para: EPUB3 does not require that Reading Systems come with any particular set of built-in system fonts. As occurs in Web contexts, Users in a particular locale may have installed fonts that omit characters required for other locales, and Reading Systems may utilize intrinsic fonts or font engines that do not utilize operating system installed fonts. Embedding fonts is consequently recommended in order to ensure content is rendered as intended on a global basis.

section.title: Avoid Mixed Writing Modes
section.para: EPUB3 supports CSS styles that enable both horizontal and vertical layout and both left-to-right and right-to-left direction. Not all Reading Systems may support all of these capabilities, however, and Reading Systems may support different rendering options than the Author intended.

section.title: Embedded Fonts
section.para: EPUB3 supports two closely-related font formats: OpenType and WOFF . Reading System support for both formats is required to accommodate both traditional publishing workflows centered around OpenType and emerging Web-based workflows which utilize WOFF. For example, word processing programs used to create Publications are likely to have access only to a collection of the installed OpenType fonts, while Web-archival EPUB generators will likely only have access to WOFF resources which cannot be converted to OpenType without undesirable (and potentially unlicensed) stripping of WOFF metadata.

EPUB3 also supports both obfuscated and regular font resources for both OpenType and WOFF font formats. Support for obfuscated font resources is required to accommodate font licensing restrictions for many commercially-available fonts.

section.title: Scripting
section.para: EPUB3 supports scripting via JavaScript, as defined in HTML5 and SVG (refer to for more information). It is important to note, however, that scripting support is optional for Reading Systems, and may be disabled for security reasons. As a result, Authors should not create content that requires scripts to be run. As well, Authors should be aware that scripting in an EPUB publication can create security considerations that are different than scripting within a Web browser. For example, typical same origin policy restrictions are not applicable to content that has been downloaded to a User's local system. Therefore, it is strongly encouraged that scripting be limited to container constrained contexts, as further described in .

s that contain scripted content must be marked accordingly in the Publication's manifest. Scripting should be used only when essential to the User experience, as it greatly increases the likelihood that content will not be portable across all Reading Systems and creates barriers to accessibility and content reusability.
Several mechanisms in EPUB can further minimize and constrain scripting within publications:

listitem.para: The declarative trigger element added to the EPUB XHTML5 profile enables image or textual elements to act as controls for audio and video playback (for example, to start, stop and pause playback). This element eliminates the common use of scripting to include similar functionality.

The mediaType element provides a means of encapsulating script-based support for rendering custom XML vocabularies or other custom content types, as well as for future-proof Publications in case such content types are natively supported in future Reading Systems.

The semantic inflection capability provided by the type attribute, enables Authors to provide hints to Reading Systems about content properties. One use case is to define elements such as images and video as having a zoomable property value, in which case a Reading System may provide a means for Users to access an expanded view that is out-of-line with the normal layout. Such rollover effects are typically implemented via scripting in Web contexts, but scripting cannot be readily implemented given the wide variety of layouts that a Reading System may generate.

section.title: Text-to-speech Support
section.para: This section reviews the text-to-speech facilities (TTS) that provide Authors of s a standard way to control aspects of speech synthesis such as pronunciation, volume, pitch and rate.

listitem.para: The inclusion of generic pronunciation lexicons using the W3C PLS format enables Authors to provide pronunciation rules that apply to the entire EPUB Publication. Refer to for more information. The PLS MIME type string is included in .

The incorporation of SSML phonemes functionality directly into a enables fine-grained pronunciation control, taking precedence over default pronunciation rules and/or referenced pronunciation lexicons (as provided by the PLS format mentioned above). Refer to for more information.

The inclusion of a select set of features from the CSS 3 Speech Module (previously known as CSS 2.1 Aural Stylesheets ) enables Authors to control further speech synthesis options, such as voice pitch and rate. Refer to for more information.

section.title: Introduction
section.para: A major goal of EPUB is to facilitate content accessibility, and a variety of features in EPUB3 support this requirement. This section reviews these features in the context of some established best practices for ensuring that EPUB Publications are accessible.

One of the key new accessibility features in EPUB3 is the inclusion of s . Media Overlays provide the abilty to synchronize pre-recorded audio narration with the text of a Content Document, a feature already familiar to readers of DAISY Digital Talking Books.
EPUB3 also improves on NCX documents with the addition of s. As noted in above, the new features these provide represents a more universal and flexible navigation system.

It is important to note that while accessibility is important in its own right, accessible content is also more valuable content: an accessible publication will be adaptable to more devices and be easier to reuse, in whole or in part, via human and automated workflows. The EPUB Working Group strongly recommends that Authors use EPUB tools that generate accessible content.

section.title: Ensure Full Navigation
section.para: The need to navigate a document is not exclusively an accessibility issue, but a complete is key to being able to easily and fully access the contents of a document. Authors should always ensure that the primary toc nav element (as defined in ) fully reflects the structure of their documents.

For highly structured documents, it may not be desirable to display the complete table of contents to Users, but the display level can be modified using the CSS display property without minimizing the information that is available for accessible s.
Authors should supply additional nav elements if their Publications contain non-structural points of interest, such as figures, tables, etc. to further enhance access to the content.

section.title: Create Semantically-Rich Markup
section.para: Authors should strive to make the markup in their s as semantically rich as possible, as the more detail a document contains the easier it is for Reading Systems to discover and interact with those documents.

HTML5 supports a number of new elements intended to make markup more semantically meaningful (section, nav, aside) as well as introduces more clearly defined semantics for some HTML4 elements. These elements, in conjunction with best practices for authoring well-structured Web content should be utilized when creating EPUB XHTML Content Documents. These additions allow content to be better grouped and defined, both for representing the structure of documents and to facilitate their logical navigation. XHTML Content Documents also natively support the inclusion of ARIA role and state attributes and events, enhancing the ability of Assistive Technologies to interact with the content.

EPUB3 further introduces the attribute, which is meant to be functionally equivalent to the W3C Role Attribute . This attribute allows any element in an XHTML Content Document to include additional information about its purpose and meaning within the work, using controlled vocabularies and terms. Refer to for more information.

section.title: Use Dynamic Layouts
section.para: The design center of EPUB is dynamic layout — content is typically intended to be formatted on the fly rather than being typeset in a paginated manner in advance (i.e. expecting a particular sized "page"). This core capability is useful, for example, for optimizing rendering onto different sized device screens or window sizes, and also facilitates and simplifies content accessibility vs. formats that are inherently final-form (such as bitmap page images and PDF).

While it is possible to incorporate more highly formatted content in EPUB, for example via bitmap images or SVG graphics, or even use of CSS explicit positioning and/or table elements to achieve particular visual layouts, Authors are strongly discouraged from utilizing such techniques. They are not reliable in EPUB, since Reading Systems typically render content in a paginated manner rather than creating a single scrolling , and the particular pagination algorithm used is Reading System dependent. If these techniques are required to convey the content of the publication (for example, for graphic novels), fallbacks should always be included.
In general, it is preferable to achieve visual richness by using s without explicit sizing or positioning.

section.title: Include Aural Rendering
section.para: Aural renditions of content are important for accessibility and are a desirable feature for many other Users. A baseline to facilitate aural rendering is to utilize semantic HTML designed for dynamic layout. Refer to for more information on how to use the native facilities that EPUB XHTML Documents include.
When pre-recorded audio narration is available for a Publication, EPUB3 also allows s for synchronizing the audio and text presentation for Users. Refer to for more information.

section.title: Provide Fallbacks
section.para: Not all formats are accessible in their native format, and not all Users may prefer to read in the default format provided. EPUB defines a variety of means for providing fallbacks so that alternate renditions of a Publication can be made available in these cases.
Publication and content-level fallbacks are defined in . These allow for the alternate rendition of specific resources within a Publication, such as SVG images or video clips.

In addition, multiple instances of a complete work can be delivered in a single Publication by defining multiple rootfile elements in the OCF container file (as described in ). This kind of fallback may be used, for example, to deliver a formatted graphic novel defined via a sequence of SVG pages to be accompanied by a textual version defined via XHTML.

section.title: Avoid Scripting
section.para: Although EPUB3 supports scripting in Content Documents (as defined in ), programmatic scripting presents inherent accessibility challenges.

Best practices for use of scripting in Web documents should be consulted, such as provided in the WAI-ARIA 1.0 Primer , and use of scripting should be reserved for situations in which interactivity is critical to the User experience.
